h2.div: Governor Inslee announces that schools will be closed for the 2019-20 school year.

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.a: Please read the latest message from Superintendent Mike Merlino

h3.div: Нажмите здесь, чтобы прочитать по-русски | Haga clic aquí para leer la versión en español
Meals sites : Beginning on Tuesday, March 17, we will be feeding any student or community child through this program.

div.p: UPDATE: Starting April 6, Evergreen Public Schools will again be using buses to deliver meals. Food will still be available at 27 school sites.

Bus Delivery: We are providing meal delivery via 24 bus routes with more than 80 stops across the district. Between 8:30am and 9:30am, buses will stop at each location for approximately 10 minutes to serve meals. The bus routes can be seen by using the map available below.

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: BUS DROP OFF LOCATIONS

div.class: hJDwNd-AhqUyc-uQSCkd jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque GNzUNc

em.strong: These schools will be open for breakfast/lunch “grab and go” meals from 9:00 a.m.-11:00 a.m.:

ul.li: Covington Middle School (11200 NE Rosewood Ave.)

em.strong: These schools will be open for breakfast/lunch “grab and go” meals from 9:00 a.m.-10:00 a.m.:

ul.li: Burnt Bridge Creek Elementary (14619 NE 49th St.)
Columbia Valley Elementary (17500 SE Sequoia Circle)
Endeavour Elementary (2701 NE Four Seasons Lane)
Fisher’s Landing Elementary (3800 SE Hiddenbrook Dr.)
Mountain View High School ( 1500 SE Blairmont Drive)

div.p: If you have extenuating circumstances needing our program meals for your child and cannot access one of our sites, we will review requests submitted here: Delivery Request for Meal Pick-up Hardship. Requests for meal delivery are not guaranteed and it is unlikely that we can accommodate every request.

Staff and community safety while serving the need for meals is our objective. For this meal service to continue, please follow health and safety department recommendations for limiting the spread of virus exposure. Practice 6’ distance rules to the best of your ability and do not collect meals if you are symptomatic or been exposed to anyone symptomatic.

div.class: hJDwNd-AhqUyc-uQSCkd jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque GNzUNc

div.p: We will make reasonable modifications to meals in effort to accommodate disabilities that restrict a child’s diet. Please understand these are not usual operations during this time and we are working diligently to accommodate individual needs. Your patience is appreciated.

If your child is an EPS student with a dietary prescription already on file and your child intends to participate in the available meal service during the COVID-19 school closures, please email nutrition.services@evergreenps.org your child’s name, usual attending school, grade, and the school your child will be receiving a meal from. We will need 24-hours to fulfill requests for delivery.

If your child does not already have a dietary prescription form on file and needs meal substitutions during our COVID-19 school closure meal services, please complete our dietary prescription form and submit it to nutrition.services@evergreenps.org along with the school and pick-up location.
Many families will be facing hardships while the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic continue. Here are ways you may obtain or offer assistance.

p.strong: USDA National School Breakfast and Lunch Program

div.p: Households may apply for USDA NSLP/SBP Free and Reduced-price meal benefits at any time through the end of the school year and again starting in August. Even if you’ve previously applied and were denied benefits, you may reapply if household circumstances have changed. To apply:

ul.li: Applications are available on our website and can be turned in or mailed to the Nutrition Services (CNS) office at the EPS Administrative Services Center.
The primary household parents can also apply online via their Skyward Family Access login.

h3.div: Student Meal Accounts for Food Service When School Resumes

div.p: Schools and districts nationwide are carrying growing student meal account debt as we continue to feed students regardless of sufficient account funds. As of the COVID-19 school closure, more than 4600 EPS students owe approximately $139,000 in combined outstanding meal charges. We expect this will grow when service resumes.
Monetary donations to assist with either outstanding meal account debts or meal account funding going forward can be given to the Nutrition Services office at the EPS Administrative Services Center.
Продовольственные Ресурсы | Recursos de Alimentos

Share’s Backpack Program Food Bags will be available to any family at the following locations on Thursday, April 23rd from 9:00 a.m. - 11:00 a.m. or until they are gone. The bags will be distributed through a drive-thru or walk-up “grab and go” system to maintain safe social distancing.
· Burton Elementary (14015 NE 28th St.)
· Crestline Elementary (13003 SE 7th St.)
· Ellsworth Elementary (512 SE Ellsworth Road)
· Fircrest Elementary (12001 NE 9th St.) from 9:00 a.m. - 10:00 a.m. only
· Hearthwood Elementary (801 NE Hearthwood Blvd.)
· Heritage High School (7825 NE 130th Ave.)
· Image Elementary (4400 NE 122nd Ave.) from 9:00 a.m. - 10:00 a.m. only
· Mill Plain Elementary (400 NE 164th Ave.)
· Silver Star Elementary (10500 NE 86th St.)

The food bags will provide a small amount of nonperishable food items that may include: cereal, canned chili, canned ravioli, shelf-stable 1% milk, canned fruit, pasta or rice, pasta sauce, mac ‘n cheese, canned vegetables, or similar items.

EPS families are welcome to visit the location most convenient for them, regardless of where their child attends school. This schedule may be subject to change, please check the district website for updates.

Are you in need of food assistance? For a complete list of Food Pantry Sites during the COVID-19 outbreak, please visit the Clark County Food Bank website. They have created a “COVID-19” tab that updates pantry sites and hours in real time. Because news is changing rapidly, they recommend calling the pantry before going to ensure they are open during the COVID-19 outbreak.
For other community resources you may find helpful during this time, please visit the COVID-19 Community Resources Page.

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: COVID-19 COMMUNITY RESOURCES PAGE

Food donations are critical, now more than ever. If you would like to make a donation, we suggest food donations be directed towards the Clark County Food Bank to support our community. The food that provides the least amount of risk right now is shelf-stable products. Their most needed items are peanut butter, canned soup and canned meat. Please take food donations to the Clark County Food Bank (6502 NE 47th Ave.) and leave in the donation bin outside their warehouse. If you have any questions about donating food, please contact the Clark County Food Bank at food@clarkcountyfoodbank.org

a.aria-label: Message from Superintendent Mike Merlino on Virtual Learning plans

div.p: Message from Superintendent Mike Merlino on Virtual Learning plans

div.a: "Mensaje del Superintendente Mike Merlino sobre los planes para un aprendizaje virtual"

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.a: «Сообщение от Суперинтенданта Mike Merlino по поводу Планов виртуального обучения»

div.p: These resources are not meant to be a substitute for classroom instruction, however, they may help students maintain learning independently during the closure. Additionally, please encourage your student to complete previously assigned homework or ongoing projects.

div.p: Little SIS Sync Agent is an application that automates Google Classroom classes, rosters, and guardians. We are enabling the sync guardian data to support distance learning. This way our teachers do not need to manually enter email addresses of parents to receive guardian notifications.

div.class: hJDwNd-AhqUyc-wNfPc pSzOP-AhqUyc-wNfPc jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque

div.p: Special Education Updates

div.p: FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS (FAQ)
RUSSIAN | SPANISH

div.p: TECH SUPPORT REQUEST FORM
RUSSIAN | SPANISH

p.em: Our support staff will monitor requests between 8 am - 4 pm, Monday - Friday.

div.p: Comcast has opened the Xfinity WiFi network nationally for free. Follow the links below to learn more.

div.class: hJDwNd-AhqUyc-uQSCkd jXK9ad D2fZ2 OjCsFc wHaque GNzUNc

div.p: As of March 24th, SWCCC has consolidated their centers. They are only operating the following sites in the Evergreen School District: school age care at Orchards and Hearthwood, and 12 months-5 years old at Park Crest Early Learning Center.
Families who are not currently enrolled with SWCCC will need to register by phone: 360-952-3466. Families will not be able to register on site.

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: CAMP EVERGREEN REGISTRATION

Camp Evergreen is free for children of our community's First Responders and Healthcare Professionals during the COVID-19 crisis. Camp Evergreen will be located at Crestline Elementary School, 13003 SE 7th Street Vancouver 98683 beginning Tuesday, March 24 from M-F from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. We will be accepting children 30 months through 12 years of age.

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: Class of 2020 webpage

Our district will continue to communicate with our partners: The Office of Public Instruction (OSPI), State Board of Education, colleges, community colleges and universities that provide credit bearing classes for our students. Additionally, OSPI and the State Board of Education will be providing guidance with regard to graduation requirement issues. We will guide all of our seniors toward graduation and you can rest assured that our students will not be negatively impacted as a result of events beyond their control. That is our commitment to you.

Grading - For high school semester two final grades, students may choose to receive a pass or no credit option or a traditional letter grade on their high school transcript. Students must notify their teachers by June 1st. Students not making their choice will receive the pass or no credit grade on their transcript. Pass or no credit grades do not impact cumulative GPAs. Students in dual credit courses may only earn college credit by selecting the letter grade. If you are maintaining NCAA eligibility, please check with the clearinghouse before choosing an option. Counselors and principals will also be supporting students in this decision as needed.

Credits - EPS has applied for the emergency waiver through the State Board of Education that gives principals the ability to waive credit-based graduation requirements if the student was previously on track to graduate this school year. Counselors and administrators will work with individual students where this may apply.

Graduation - Graduation is a significant event that celebrates each student’s journey. It is also a celebration for each student’s family. We will be working with staff and students to plan a virtual ceremony in June, and we will also plan on having a traditional graduation ceremony at the earliest, safe date allowed by our state. EPS is committed to providing a graduation ceremony for all of our seniors.
High School and Beyond Plans: To be determined.
Counselors: High School counselors are available via email and are working to create systems of support.

SAT exams: The makeup exam scheduled for March 28, and an exam scheduled for May 2, have been canceled. Registered students will receive a refund. Students can go to https://www.collegeboard.org/ for updated information.
ACT exams: ACT has rescheduled its April 4 national test date to June 13. Students can go to https://www.act.org/ for more information.
Running Start: Check the Clark College website for updates: http://www.clark.edu/.

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue; focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: AP CORONAVIRUS TESTING UPDATES

The 2019-20 AP Exam administration will be given from May 11-22. Make-up test dates will be from June 1-5. Each AP subject exam will be taken at the same day and time worldwide. The detailed schedule can be found here.
· Details on exam length, format, and structure can be found here.
· Student may take the exam at home or schools may coordinate and offer the exam at school (if open).
· Full details of exam specifications for each AP subject are posted on this page.

· Online AP Courses continue to be available on AP's YouTube channel. These free lessons are delivered by AP teachers from across the country. The AP Course Schedule has been posted which now includes all AP courses.
· AP Coronavirus Updates- General page where all information and updates are posted.
· AP Coronavirus- Student Page
· AP Coronavirus- FAQ
· AP Customer Service:
o Email: apexams@info.collegeboard.org
If your students need mobile tools or connectivity, you can let us know by April 24, and we will do our best to connect students with resources.

li.strong: Why are school buildings closed for the rest of the 2019-20 school year ?

div.p: Evergreen Public Schools is following the directive of Washington’s Governor Jay Inslee. Governor Inslee closed all schools in the State of Washington for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year.. This is to allow for social distancing to reduce the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) in our community and state.

li.strong: How will this closure affect high school seniors?

div.p: High school seniors will continue to receive support from school counselors, administrators, and other staff on completing graduation requirements. We are closely following guidance from OSPI and the State Board of Education on flexibility with meeting the requirements.
Graduation: We are exploring all options and will have more information in the near future.
Please refer to the College Board site for Advanced Placement (AP) testing updates: COLLEGE BOARD CORONAVIRUS UPDATES

Due to the emergency closure of schools by Governor Inslee, high school students and middle school students earning high school credits will have two options for how final grades will be posted. Additionally, the governor has stated that student grades will not be harmed as a result of the closure. Student grades may only increase during this time.

For high school semester two final grades, students may choose to receive a pass or no credit option or a traditional letter grade on their high school transcript. Students must notify their teachers by June 1st. Students not making their choice will receive the pass or no credit grade on their transcript. Pass or no credit grades do not impact cumulative GPAs. Students in dual credit courses may only earn college credit by selecting the letter grade. If you are maintaining NCAA eligibility, please check with the clearinghouse before choosing an option. Counselors and principals will also be supporting students in this decision as needed.

For middle school trimester three final grades, students will be receiving a pass or no credit grade. Middle school students taking high school level courses will be graded in the same manner as high school students.

Elementary school report cards will be completed by June 15th. Teachers will record marks for all applicable areas which apply under distance learning circumstances; some areas will not be able to be assessed and will be marked with an asterisk.

li.strong: How do I talk to my child about the Coronavirus?

div.p: Our Social Emotional Learning page has resources to help both children and adults during these uncertain times.

li.strong: What are ways that parents can deal with the stress and anxiety related to these events?

div.p: The Centers For Disease Control & Prevention has an excellent resource page. Our Social Emotional Learning page has additional information.

Food donations are critical, now more than ever. If you would like to make a donation, we suggest food donations be directed towards the Clark County Food Bank to support our community. The food that provides the least amount of risk right now is shelf-stable products. Their most needed items are peanut butter, canned soup and canned meat. Please take food donations to the Clark County Food Bank (6502 NE 47th Ave.) and leave in the donation bin outside their warehouse. If you have any questions about donating food, please contact the Clark County Food Bank at food@clarkcountyfoodbank.org

li.strong: How can I pick up my child’s medications that are in the school health room?

div.p: Please contact the district’s Health Services Department at 360-604-6704 to arrange for a pick-up time.

li.strong: What about building rentals? Can we still use schools in off-hours?

div.p: All events in our schools have been canceled or postponed. For more information you can contact Building Rentals at rentals@evergreenps.org or by phone (360) 604-4009.
